cards.title: Greek referendum / What are your hopes?

item.title: Greek referendum: share your photos and experiences
item.trailText: What‚Äôs the mood where you are? Whether you‚Äôre in Athens, Kos or Santorini we‚Äôd like to see your pictures and hear your thoughts and hopes
item.standFirst: What‚Äôs the mood where you are? Whether you‚Äôre in Athens, Kos or Santorini we‚Äôd like to see your pictures and hear your thoughts and hopes
item.body:
10 million Greeks are casting their yes or no vote in a referendum that will decide whether to accept a bailout package drawn up by creditors. The referendum poses the biggest challenge to the Euro since its adoption in 1999. Are you voting today? What are your hopes? What‚Äôs the mood like where you are? Share your photos, thoughts and hopes with us.

We‚Äôll use the most interesting contributions in our reporting.

You can share your views with GuardianWitness by clicking on the blue ‚ÄòContribute‚Äô buttons on this article. You can also use the GuardianWitness smartphone app or the Guardian app and search for ‚ÄòGuardianWitness assignments.‚Äô

  • GuardianWitness is the home of readers‚Äô content on the Guardian. Contribute your video, pictures and stories, and browse news, reviews and creations submitted by others. Posts will be reviewed prior to publication on GuardianWitness, and the best pieces will feature on the Guardian site

cards.title: Books about Las Vegas / Readers' picks

item.title: Books about Las Vegas: readers' picks
item.trailText: Winning in Las Vegas makes a good story, but losing sometimes makes an even better one. Here are our readers‚Äô favourite books about Sin City
item.standFirst:
Winning in Las Vegas makes a good story, but losing sometimes makes an even better one. Here are our readers‚Äô favourite books about Sin City

  • Maile Chapman introduces the literature of Las Vegas
item.body:
‚ÄúHalf-meritocracy and half crap-shoot, Las Vegas is [...] the only city in America where the odds against you are all posted in plain sight, literally and metaphorically,‚Äù wrote Maile Chapman last week. Do read her blogpost about the essential Vegas literature ‚Äì from Fear and Loathing to recent fiction about the struggles of life in the city beyond the Strip ‚Äì but are there ever enough books in a list? Our readers had plenty more to contribute, and here are their picks.

1. Super Casino: Inside the ‚ÄúNew‚Äù Las Vegas by Pete Earley (2001)

Journalist and author Pete Earley wrote this book which mixes the history of the city‚Äôs gambling business and character sketches and vignettes of life. In the words of the author:

I wanted to discover what draws people there so I went ‚Äúinside‚Äù the Luxor, a billion dollar, pyramid-shaped casino on the Strip. I tell the story through the eyes of the people who I met ‚Äî a workaholic casino boss, a seasoned blackjack whiz, a showgirl ‚Äî even a teenage hooker who dreams of someday becoming a casino dealer.

understruck recommended it: ‚ÄúIt delves into the history and current mechanics.‚Äù

2. Vegas: A Memoir of a Dark Season by John Gregory Dunne (1974)

This long-out-of-print novel was the first from Dunne, aka Mr Joan Didion. According to a review in Kirkus: ‚ÄúIn the middle of his thirty-seventh year and first nervous breakdown, reading obits of college pals in the alumni rag, the husband-author manque of Joan Didion rents an apartment in the town that‚Äôs always open. In between sleeping and TV quiz shows he gets to know some of the occasionally wealthy but always degenerate desperate citizens: comic Jackie Kasey, who gets $10,000 a week but drives himself crazy with lack of fame and status games like ‚Äútaking steam‚Äù with Frankie or Sammy or Cosby; Artha the hooker who turned 1203 tricks with 1076 johns in five years, including 54 ‚Äúmultiples,‚Äù 24 S and 1 M; and Buster Mano, the private dick, who traces straying conventioneering hubbies and hustles gambling debts.‚Äù Sounds more than promising.

A ‚Äúwonderful novel‚Äù according to ID5882060, despite its low sales and almost unknown status. This Esquire magazine piece dubbed it ‚Äúthe best Las Vegas book you‚Äôve never read‚Äù.

3. The Stand by Stephen King (1978)

The master of horror‚Äôs The Stand ‚Äì published first in 1978 and re-published in 1990 as an ‚Äúuncut edition‚Äù, at 1,100 pages ‚Äì is a giant post-apocalyptic novel that is considered one of his most important works by fans and critics. James Smythe wrote in the Guardian: ‚ÄúWhile I knew I loved King before that holiday [where he read it], afterwards I‚Äôd have followed him to hell and back. It‚Äôs because of The Stand that I‚Äôve read all his work, and that I embarked on this series; it‚Äôs because of The Stand that I‚Äôm a writer at all.‚Äù ‚ÄúFor me, the writing of Stephen King starts and ends with The Stand,‚Äù wrote author Richard Thomas on Buzzfeed.

‚ÄúNothing in The Stand is an accident. As much as it‚Äôs a novel about the battle between good and evil, it‚Äôs also a novel about fate. These people ‚Äì the American contingent of the 0.6% of the world‚Äôs population who survived Captain Trips ‚Äì manage to meet up in Las Vegas, called from all around by dreams. Did they choose to find each other, or was it chosen for them?‚Äù continued Smythe. The novel was recommended by reader CoronationChicken.

In quotes from the book:

Who gets to be bexst-liked in any community? Who is the most trusted? Why, the man who does the dirty job, of course, and does it with a smile. The man who does the job you couldn‚Äôt bring yourself to do.

Dreams are the psyche‚Äôs way of taking a good dump every now and then. And that people who dream ‚Äì or don‚Äôt dream in a way they can often remember when they wake up ‚Äì are mentally constipated in some way.

4. Fools Die (1978) and Inside Las Vegas (1977) by Mario Puzo

The author of The Godfather wrote two books set in this city: the novel Fools Die, recommended by banjodsp, and the non-fiction Inside Las Vegas, a ‚Äúworld-weary account of the place‚Äù according to Face56. These are also examples of an author from elswehere (New York in this case, of course) settling in the city for a while and translating the experience into fiction and memoir. Apparently, Puzo himself was a ‚Äúdegenerate gambler‚Äù ‚Äì but he believed Las Vegas was an honest, clean city.

In quotes from the book:

Let us be separated by wars and pestilence, death, madness but not by the passing of time. ‚Äì Fools Die

The fact of the matter is that I wanted to hold a grudge in some funny kind of way. Against everybody. ‚ÄìFools Die

It can be argued that man‚Äôs instinct to gamble is the only reason he is still not a monkey up in the trees. ‚Äì Inside Las Vegas

With the perverse logic of a degenerate gambler he figured God was testing his faith. ‚Äì Inside Las Vegas

5. In Nevada: The Land, the People, God, and Chance by David Thomson (1999)

Even though this history book covers the whole state, it ‚Äúcentres very much on the neon heart of the action,‚Äù said reader leroyhunter. Flm critic David Thomson‚Äôs study of the American West promises to be ‚Äúpart contemplation of an America both austere and flamboyant, part love letter to the Old West, part idiosyncratic travel guide‚Äù and to enlighten readers on why ‚ÄúNevada is the place where Samuel Clemens became Mark Twain, Frank Sinatra became chairman of the board, divorce became an industry and gambling an institution...‚Äù Thomson also uses his huge knowledge of film and Hollywood to show how movies like The Godfather, Goodfellas, Casino and The Misfits ‚Äúhave shaped and played upon our preconceptions about Nevada and Las Vegas‚Äù, said a New York Times review.

In quotes from the book:

Nevada is on the edge, on the wire, off to one side, in the empty quarter, or even in the rest of the country‚Äôs head as an idea, a possibility, an alternative. It is an experiment, or a kind of theater ... for America has used Nevada as a testing ground, and not just for weapons and their destructiveness but also for new social ideas, and their explosiveness. What happens if you allow divorce, prostitution, gambling? Can there be community and purpose if you encourage things deep in human nature yet supposedly alien to order and togetherness?

6. About a Mountain by John D‚ÄôAgata (2010)

This unique book is a lyric essay about the proposed Yucca Mountain nuclear waste repository, an area for storage of spent nuclear fuel (from the entire United States) about 100 miles away from Las Vegas (in the plans of the government since the 80s). When D‚ÄôAgata helped his mother move to Las Vegas in the summer 2002, the US Congress was going ahead with the plans, and the writer and essayist stayed to look into the history of it all (as well as investigate the mysterious suicide of a boy who jumped off a hotel-casino). The format of the book has also been called ‚Äúa reporter‚Äôs notebook that reads like poetry‚Äù by NPR. D‚ÄôAgata has ‚Äúan encyclopedic understanding of the form‚Äôs intricate artistry‚Äù, according to the New York Times. It was ‚Äúwholeheartedly recommended‚Äù by Ce_Santiago.

7. The Goldfinch by Donna Tartt (2013)

Donna Tartt‚Äôs bestselling and Pulitzer Prize-winning novel is partly set in Las Vegas (as well as in Amsterdam and New York City) ‚Äì and the city‚Äôs presence in the story is very powerful, as our readers explained.

I thought the section of The Goldfinch set in Vegas was very strong, the sort of banality and frustration of trying to live a normal life in its suburbs rather than ‚Äúblah blah Sin City‚Äù... ‚Äì benzedrine

The portrayal of Las Vegas brought [the book] to a sort of life (as far as that word can be used) ‚Äì the vast desert background, the huge sky and the semi-deserted housing estate, the boys pilfering from shops for food ... It came across as a parched, sterile, hating environment, rife with low-life. Boys growing up here, while parents gambled and stole, didn‚Äôt stand a chance of taking the right path. ‚Äì JHawkinson

Definitely The Goldfinch ‚Äì incredibly evocative of the sand blasted emptiness of the suburbs. ‚Äì DeputyPeck

In quotes from the book:

Well, is true. I did know. Because if possible to paint fakes that look like that? Las Vegas would be the most beautiful city in the history of earth!

What mattered most, as I came to realize, was who‚Äôd lived in Vegas the longest, which was why the knock-down Mexican beauties and itinerant construction heirs sat alone at lunch while the bland, middling children of local realtors and car dealers were the cheerleaders and class presidents, the unchallenged elite of the school.


8. Leaving Las Vegas by John O‚ÄôBrien (1990)

A scorching novel of alcohol, love, self-destruction and suicide, it was later adapted into an Oscar-winning film, starring Nicholas Cage. Reader DeputyPeck ‚Äúthought it was heart-wrenchingly sad; no Las Vegas winners in that book.‚Äù

In quotes from the book:

Casinos ‚Ä¶ know that chips are a wonderful, pretty tool, and possess none of the stigma of dollars. Dollars translate too easily into hours or houses or cars or sex or food or everything, and so losing a dollar is a much more tangible experience than parting with a chip, an object that looks more like a midway consolation token than a medium of exchange.

9. The Underworld USA Trilogy by James Ellroy

Las Vegas is ‚Äújust up the road from Los Angeles‚Äù ‚Äì in relative, American terms ‚Äì as reader mydaray pointed out, so it was only inevitable for the quintessential LA crime writer to base some of his stories in Sin City. This trilogy, formed by the novels American Tabloid, The Cold Six Thousand and Blood‚Äôs a Rover, tells a saga of corruption in the late 50s and early 60s and includes real history ‚Äì John F Kennedy and Martin Luther King‚Äôs assassinations and the Vietnam War among other defining events ‚Äì and spans across the country. Las Vegas has a strong presence as the Mafia‚Äôs stronghold. It was also recommended by kelso77 and DJKM.

A very Ellroy-esque quote from The Cold Six Thousand

Pete pulled the blinds. Wayne hit the lights. There:

Sink water ‚Äì dark pink ‚Äì carving knives afloat. Baked beans and fruit flies on mold. Hair in a colander. Dots on the floor. Dots by the fridge.

Pete opened it. Pete smelled it. They saw it:

The severed legs. The diced hips. Mom‚Äôs head in the vegetable bin.

Extra notes

Reader ID6489058 offered a handy chronological reading list:

  • The Biggest Game In Town for the Las Vegas of 30 years ago.
  • The Odds: One Season, Three Gamblers, and the Death of Their Las Vegas for the Las Vegas of 20 years ago.
  • The Professor, The Banker, and the Suicide King: Inside the Richest Poker Game of All Time for the Las Vegas of 10 years ago.
  • Ship It Holla Ballas: How a Bunch of 19-Year-Old College Dropouts Used the Internet to Become Poker‚Äôs Loudest, Craziest, and Richest Crew for the Las Vegas of now.

cards.title: Women's World Cup final / What's the mood where you are?
cards.rawTitle: What's the mood where you are?

item.title: Women's World Cup final: what's the mood where you are?
item.trailText: Japan take on the United States in the final in Vancouver on Sunday. We‚Äôre looking for fans of both sides, wherever they are in the world, to share their stories
item.standFirst: Japan take on the United States in the final in Vancouver on Sunday. We‚Äôre looking for fans of both sides, wherever they are in the world, to share their stories
item.body:
Japan, the current holders, and past winners the US are the finalists of the 2015 Women‚Äôs World Cup. They battle it out on Sunday evening in Vancouver, completing a tournament that has captured the public imagination around the world.

Who‚Äôs going to win? We have absolutely no idea. But that‚Äôs not why you‚Äôre here, we hope. Instead, we want to hear about the pre-final mood wherever you are, what the team you support means to you, and what you think will happen on Sunday.

Obviously, we‚Äôre particularly keen to hear from Japanese and American fans, whether they‚Äôre living in these respective countries or are living far from home. Or perhaps you‚Äôre an American living in Japan, or vice versa? But wherever you are, and wherever you‚Äôre from, if you‚Äôre following the final, we want to hear from you.

Share your photos and stories via GuardianWitness by pressing the blue button, or by filling in the form below. And may the best team win.

cards.title: Life in SW19 / Fans' photos from the first week at Wimbledon
cards.rawTitle: Fans' photos from the first week at Wimbledon

item.title: Life in SW19: fans' photos from the first week at Wimbledon 2015
item.trailText: With Wimbledon 2015 nearing the halfway stage, here‚Äôs a roundup of fans‚Äô photos on social media from the first week of the tournament
item.standFirst: With Wimbledon 2015 nearing the halfway stage, here‚Äôs a roundup of fans‚Äô photos on social media from the first week of the tournament
item.body: Wimbledon 2015 is nearing its halfway stage, and with the heat firmly on the remaining players as well as the large crowds queueing for tickets or already enjoying Centre Court action, we‚Äôve rounded up a selection of fans‚Äô photos of their experiences during the tournament‚Äôs first week.

headerImage.caption: Selfie time on Murray Mound Photograph: ID899111/GuardianWitness

cards.title: Liam Williams webchat at MIF / Post your questions now

item.title: Liam Williams webchat at MIF ‚Äì¬†post your questions now
item.trailText: Live from Manchester international festival, outsider comedian Liam Williams will be answering your questions on Monday 6 July from 2.15pm BST onwards ‚Äì post them in the comments below
item.standFirst: Live from Manchester international festival, outsider comedian Liam Williams will be answering your questions on Monday 6 July from 2.15pm BST onwards ‚Äì post them in the comments below

blocks.title: Post your questions for Liam Williams
blocks.body:
At the heart of Liam Williams‚Äôs comedy is the suspicion that everything is a bit rubbish, whether it‚Äôs pop culture, social inequality, or ultimately his own life. But he‚Äôs no insufferable sad-sack: his lacerations of himself and others reflect a desire to really feel and truly live.

This impassioned and very funny material, about anything from porn to mindfulness, won him a nomination as best newcomer at last year‚Äôs Edinburgh festival. He‚Äôs been around for a while though, with his surreal sketch trio Sheeps first hitting the fringe in 2010. He also played host at the recent comedy gigs in Parliament Square, held by the Occupy movement as part of their Festival of Democracy.

Next up is a stint at Manchester international festival alongside his peers from comedy venue The Invisible Dot, doing a nightly cabaret. He‚Äôll join us live from the festival to answer your questions in a webchat, from 2.15pm onwards on Monday 6 July ‚Äì post your questions in the comments below, and he‚Äôll answer as many as possible.

keyEvents.title: Post your questions for Liam Williams
keyEvents.body:

This impassioned and very funny material, about anything from porn to mindfulness, won him a nomination as best newcomer at last year‚Äôs Edinburgh festival. He‚Äôs been around for a while though, with his surreal sketch trio Sheeps first hitting the fringe in 2010. He also played host at the recent comedy gigs in Parliament Square, held by the Occupy movement as part of their Festival of Democracy.

Next up is a stint at Manchester international festival alongside his peers from comedy venue The Invisible Dot, doing a nightly cabaret. He‚Äôll join us live from the festival to answer your questions in a webchat, from 2.15pm onwards on Monday 6 July ‚Äì post your questions in the comments below, and he‚Äôll answer as many as possible.

cards.title: Ten years on from 7/7 / Share your memories

item.title: 7/7 10 years on: share your memories
item.trailText: Even if you weren‚Äôt directly affected by the shocking events of 7 July 2005, many will remember that day. Share your memories via GuardianWitness
item.standFirst: Even if you weren‚Äôt directly affected by the shocking events of 7 July 2005, many will remember that day. Share your memories via GuardianWitness
item.body:
It is now ten years since four bombs were detonated in London during rush hour, killing 52 and injuring more than 700. Even if you weren‚Äôt in London that day the scale and effect of the attacks had a huge impact across the UK.

Whether you were in London or elsewhere, we‚Äôd like to hear your memories of that day. How did you find out about the events? Did you follow the live news coverage? Were you personally affected by the attacks? Perhaps you were also in London that morning ‚Äì or were anxious about relatives and friends? Was there any lasting impact?

Share your memories and stories and we‚Äôll use the most interesting contributions in our reporting.

You can share your memories with GuardianWitness by clicking on the blue ‚ÄòContribute‚Äô buttons on this article. You can also use the GuardianWitness smartphone app or the Guardian app and search for ‚ÄòGuardianWitness assignments.‚Äô

  • GuardianWitness is the home of readers‚Äô content on the Guardian. Contribute your video, pictures and stories, and browse news, reviews and creations submitted by others. Posts will be reviewed prior to publication on GuardianWitness, and the best pieces will feature on the Guardian site

cards.title: Your pictures / Share your photographs on the theme of 'note'
cards.rawTitle: Share your photographs on the theme of 'note'

item.title: Your pictures: share your photographs on the theme of 'note'
item.trailText: Wherever you are in the world, we‚Äôd like to see your pictures of ‚Äònote.‚Äô Share your best photos via GuardianWitness
item.standFirst:
Wherever you are in the world, we‚Äôd like to see your pictures of ‚Äònote.‚Äô Share your best photos via GuardianWitness

  • Readers‚Äô pictures on the theme of ‚Äòarrow‚Äô
item.body:
We‚Äôre now running a regular weekly photography assignment in the Observer New Review and the next theme is ‚Äònote.‚Äô So whether it‚Äôs a piece of music that you‚Äôre learning, a written reminder on your fridge or paying attention to something, share your photos of what note means to you ‚Äì and tell us about your image in the description box.

The closing date is Thursday 9 July at 10 am. We‚Äôll publish our favourites in The New Review on 12 July and in a gallery on the Guardian site.

You can share your ‚Äònote‚Äô pictures by clicking on the blue ‚ÄòContribute‚Äô button on this article. You can also use the GuardianWitness smartphone app or the Guardian app and search for ‚ÄòGuardianWitness assignments‚Äô ‚Äì and if you add it to the homepage ‚Äì you can keep up with all our assignments.

  • GuardianWitness is the home of readers‚Äô content on the Guardian. Contribute your video, pictures and stories, and browse news, reviews and creations submitted by others.
